title: Gerund & Infinitive
description: Слушайте и различайте герундий и инфинитив после глаголов.

tasks.audioText: After years of hesitation, Mark finally decided to start his own business. He enjoys working independently and setting his own schedule.
tasks.transcript: He enjoys working independently and setting his own schedule.

options.text: He likes being his own boss and choosing when to work.
He wants to find a new job with flexible hours.
He stopped working because of the schedule.
He avoids making decisions about his schedule.

tasks.explanation: 'Enjoy' is followed by a gerund (-ing). 'Enjoys working' means he likes the process of working independently.

tasks.audioText: Sarah had a long day at the office. On her way home, she stopped to buy some groceries for dinner.
tasks.transcript: On her way home, she stopped to buy some groceries for dinner.

options.text: She quit buying groceries altogether.
She paused her journey in order to purchase food.
She finished shopping before leaving work.
She continued driving without stopping anywhere.

tasks.explanation: 'Stop to do' means to pause in order to do something else. She interrupted her trip home to go shopping.

tasks.audioText: The doctor warned Tom about his unhealthy habits. Tom needs to quit smoking as soon as possible.
tasks.transcript: Tom needs to quit smoking as soon as possible.

options.text: Tom should start smoking less frequently.
Tom plans to smoke more in the future.
Tom must stop the habit of smoking immediately.
Tom refused to listen to his doctor's advice.

tasks.explanation: 'Quit' is followed by a gerund. 'Quit smoking' means to completely stop the habit of smoking.

tasks.audioText: Lisa is incredibly talented but lacks confidence. She can't help feeling nervous before every presentation.
tasks.transcript: She can't help feeling nervous before every presentation.

options.text: She deliberately makes herself nervous before presenting.
She never feels nervous during presentations.
She is unable to avoid getting nervous before presentations.
She helps others overcome their nervousness.

tasks.explanation: 'Can't help doing' means being unable to prevent oneself from doing something. It's an involuntary reaction.

tasks.audioText: The company offered James a promotion last month. He refused to accept it because it required relocating abroad.
tasks.transcript: He refused to accept it because it required relocating abroad.

options.text: He turned down the promotion since it meant moving to another country.
He happily accepted the promotion and moved abroad.
He asked for more time to consider the relocation.
He accepted the promotion but stayed in his current city.

tasks.explanation: 'Refuse' takes a to-infinitive, while 'require' takes a gerund. He said no because moving abroad was necessary.

tasks.audioText: My grandmother is eighty years old but very active. She keeps forgetting where she put her glasses.
tasks.transcript: She keeps forgetting where she put her glasses.

options.text: She remembers exactly where her glasses are.
She repeatedly forgets the location of her glasses.
She intentionally hides her glasses from others.
She stopped wearing glasses recently.

tasks.explanation: 'Keep doing' means to continue doing something repeatedly. She forgets again and again where her glasses are.

tasks.audioText: The students were struggling with the assignment. The professor suggested breaking the project into smaller tasks.
tasks.transcript: The professor suggested breaking the project into smaller tasks.

options.text: The professor recommended dividing the work into manageable parts.
The professor told students to abandon the project entirely.
The professor assigned an additional project to the class.
The professor refused to help the struggling students.

tasks.explanation: 'Suggest' is always followed by a gerund, never a to-infinitive. 'Suggested breaking' means recommended splitting it up.

tasks.audioText: We were driving through the countryside when it started raining. We decided to stop driving and wait at a cafe.
tasks.transcript: We decided to stop driving and wait at a cafe.

options.text: We chose to continue driving despite the rain.
We made the choice to cease driving and rest at a cafe.
We stopped at a cafe to start driving again.
We drove faster to reach the cafe before the rain.

tasks.explanation: 'Decide' takes a to-infinitive. 'Stop driving' (stop + gerund) means to cease the activity of driving.

tasks.audioText: Elena is considering several career options. She is thinking about applying to a graduate program in psychology.
tasks.transcript: She is thinking about applying to a graduate program in psychology.

options.text: She already enrolled in a psychology program.
She rejected the idea of studying psychology.
She is contemplating submitting an application for a psychology degree.
She finished her graduate program last year.

tasks.explanation: After prepositions like 'about,' we always use a gerund. 'Thinking about applying' means she is considering it but hasn't decided yet.

tasks.audioText: The new employee is very diligent and motivated. He promised to finish the report before the Friday deadline.
tasks.transcript: He promised to finish the report before the Friday deadline.

options.text: He gave his word that the report would be completed by Friday.
He asked for an extension on the Friday deadline.
He admitted he could not finish the report in time.
He denied being responsible for the report.

tasks.explanation: 'Promise' takes a to-infinitive. He committed to completing the work before the deadline.

tasks.audioText: I lent my neighbour some tools last week. I remember lending him the drill, but he says I didn't.
tasks.transcript: I remember lending him the drill, but he says I didn't.

options.text: I need to remember to lend him the drill later.
I have a clear memory of giving him the drill, though he denies it.
I forgot to lend him the drill entirely.
He remembers borrowing the drill from me.

tasks.explanation: 'Remember doing' refers to having a memory of a past action. 'Remember to do' means not to forget a future action.

tasks.audioText: The weather was terrible during our vacation. We regret not booking a hotel with indoor activities.
tasks.transcript: We regret not booking a hotel with indoor activities.

options.text: We are sorry that we didn't choose a hotel with things to do inside.
We are glad we picked a hotel without indoor facilities.
We plan to book a different hotel next time.
We regret to inform you that the hotel is fully booked.

tasks.explanation: 'Regret doing' means feeling sorry about a past action. The negative gerund 'not booking' expresses what they failed to do.

tasks.audioText: The children were making too much noise in the library. The librarian asked them to stop talking immediately.
tasks.transcript: The librarian asked them to stop talking immediately.

options.text: The librarian encouraged the children to speak louder.
The librarian requested that they be quiet right away.
The children asked the librarian to be quiet.
The librarian invited them to continue their conversation.

tasks.explanation: 'Ask someone to do' uses a to-infinitive. 'Stop talking' (stop + gerund) means cease the activity. The librarian wanted silence.

tasks.audioText: Anna tried a new approach to learning Spanish. She tried watching movies without subtitles to improve her listening skills.
tasks.transcript: She tried watching movies without subtitles to improve her listening skills.

options.text: She attempted to watch movies but failed every time.
She experimented with viewing films without subtitles as a learning method.
She stopped watching movies because they didn't help.
She always uses subtitles when watching foreign films.

tasks.explanation: 'Try doing' means to experiment with something as a method. 'Try to do' means to attempt something difficult.

tasks.audioText: The manager noticed some irregularities in the accounts. He denied having anything to do with the missing funds.
tasks.transcript: He denied having anything to do with the missing funds.

options.text: He admitted his involvement with the missing money.
He confirmed that he took the funds.
He said he was not connected to the disappearance of the money.
He promised to investigate the missing funds himself.

tasks.explanation: 'Deny' is always followed by a gerund. 'Denied having anything to do with' means he claimed no involvement.
